5312f6c7-ab48-4584-bd8d-b0d96545a448.description: The Energy Management Professional (EMP) certification was developed to meet and exceed the energy management standards and needs of today, demonstrating your qualifications, experience and knowledge of energy issues to clients and others. EMA’s certification holds a unique value: it is accredited by ANSI, recognized by the DOE’s Better Buildings® Program in the Building Energy Manager category and provides a commissioning-based approach to energy management.
5312f6c7-ab48-4584-bd8d-b0d96545a448.name: Energy Management Professional

alignments.name: ANSI National Accreditation Board
alignments.description: The EMP certification program is accredited by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) based on the International Standard ANSI/ISO/IEC 17024. ANSI Standard 17024 is well-recognized within the industry as the highest standard in personnel certification accreditation.

alignments.name: Department of Energy Better Buildings Workforce Recognition
alignments.description: The Department of Energy recognizes the EMP program for being aligned with the Better Buildings® Workforce Guidelines and for having received qualified accreditation by the American National Standards Institute in compliance with ISO/IEC 17024:2012.

alignments.name: ASHRAE 211 Standard for Commercial Building Energy Audits (Qualified Energy Auditor)
alignments.description: The purpose of this standard is to establish consistent practices for conducting and reporting energy audits for commercial buildings. The EMP meets the requirements established by the Standard for “Qualified Energy Auditor.”

alignments.name: Federal Building Personnel Training Act (FPT) Aligned
alignments.description: Federal Buildings Personnel Training Act of 2010 directs the Administrator of General Services (GSA) to: (1) identify, annually, the core competencies necessary for federal personnel performing building operations and maintenance, energy management, safety, and design functions to comply with requirements under federal law.

alignments.name: San Francisco Existing Commercial Buildings Ordinance (qualified for audits)
alignments.description: Residential buildings with 10,000 square feet or more of space that is heated or cooled and existing multifamily residential buildings with 50,000 square feet or more of space that is heated or cooled must report energy benchmarking and energy audits. The EMP is a recognized as a prerequisite to provide energy audits for ordinance compliance.

alignments.name: Orlando Building and Water Efficiency Policy
alignments.description: The Building Energy and Water Efficiency Strategy (BEWES) is focused on tracking the energy and water output of Orlando’s largest buildings. The EMP is a qualifying credential for auditing and benchmarking.

alignments.name: City of San Jose Building Energy and Water Building Performance Ordinance
alignments.description: Under this ordinance affected building owners must submit energy and water efficiency audits. EMPs meet the requirements to be considered a Qualified Auditor.

alignments.name: Montgomery County Benchmarking Law
alignments.description: Building owners are required to benchmark the energy use of their nonresidential buildings 50,000 square feet and greater in the county in ENERGY STAR Portfolio Manager, and report it to the County for public disclosure. The EMP is a Recognized Data Verifier for building owners reporting benchmarking information.

alignments.name: Philadelphia C-Pace Program
alignments.description: The Philadelphia C-PACE program requires that a Property Owner obtain an Energy Conservation Measure Survey (ECM Survey) performed by a Qualified Engineering Professional for Energy Efficiency and/or Water Conservation projects. EMPs are considered a Qualified Engineering Professional.

alignments.name: Boulder Building Performance Ordinance
alignments.description: The Boulder Building Performance Ordinance requires affected building owners to use qualified service providers to complete energy assessments and retrocommissioning on their buildings. EMPs are recognized under minimum qualifications for Energy Assessors.

alignments.name: Washington State Clean Buildings Bill
alignments.description: EMA’s Energy Management Professional (EMP) Certification was recognized in new rules added to the Washington State Clean Buildings Bill. The law requires that the Department of Commerce develop and implement an energy performance standard for affected buildings and provide incentives to encourage efficiency improvements.

alignments.name: Chicago Energy Benchmarking Ordinance
alignments.description: To ensure that data is being tracked and reported correctly, covered buildings must have their energy and building data reviewed and verified every three years by data verifiers with accepted licenses and training program credentials. EMPs are recognized as an approved data verifier under “Fulfill the Data Verification Requirement.”

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the application for EMP certification with documentation that the demonstrates eligibility requirements which includes: energy management education, experience and management experience. The minimum education and experience requirements are outlined in the EMP application.
Submit the application fee with the completed application.
